titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Lois Tompa "Above the Wall" poetry manuscript, 1966 MS 291
titlestmt.author: Lois Tompa

publicationstmt.publisher: Woodson Research Center, Rice University, Houston, Texas

note.p: Stored onsite at the Woodson Research Center

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2022-04-01 20:49:45 -0500.

did.head: Collection Summary

repository.corpname: Woodson Research Center, Rice University, Houston, Texas

did.unittitle: Lois Tompa "Above the Wall" poetry manuscript
did.abstract: This collection contains a hand-made collected edition of poetry by Lois Tompa called "Above the Wall", dedicated to her husband, Joseph Tompa. The manuscript consists of 35 leaves of mimeograph pages stapled together with the author's autograph inscription.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: No information is currently available on the author.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection contains a hand-made collected edition of poetry by Lois Tompa called "Above the Wall", dedicated to her husband, Joseph Tompa. The manuscript consists of 35 leaves of mimeograph pages stapled together with the author's autograph inscription.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This material is open for research.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Stored onsite at the Woodson Research Center.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: This collection was purchased with a gift from the William Stamps Farish Fund in 1967.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Lois Tompa "Above the Wall" poetry manuscript, ca. 1966, MS 291, Woodson Research Center, Fondren Library, Rice University.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Permission to publish material from the Lois Tompa Manuscript must be obtained from the Woodson Research Center, Fondren Library.

did.unittitle: Series I: Lois Tompa poetry manuscript

did.materialspec: 35 leaves of mimeograph pages stapled together with the author's autograph inscription.
